events.title: The Mystery of the Stolen Golden Apples and the Youngest Son's Vigil
detailed_summary: A king owned a garden with a tree that produced golden apples, which were counted regularly.
It was discovered that one apple went missing each night as they ripened.
The angered king ordered the gardener to have someone watch the tree all night.
The gardener's eldest son was assigned to watch first, but he fell asleep around midnight, and another apple disappeared.
The second son was then tasked with watching, but he too fell asleep at midnight, resulting in another missing apple.
The gardener's third son offered to watch. Despite initial reluctance from his father due to fear of harm, he was eventually allowed.
As midnight struck, the youngest son heard a rustling and saw a bird of pure gold flying towards the tree.
While the bird was about to take an apple, the son shot an arrow at it.
The arrow did not injure the bird, but it caused a golden feather to fall from its tail as it flew away.
The next morning, the golden feather was presented to the king and his council.
Everyone agreed the feather's value surpassed the kingdom's entire wealth.
However, the king declared that a single feather was insufficient and he must possess the entire bird.

events.text_segment: A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which bore golden apples. These apples were always counted, and about the time when they began to grow ripe it was found that every night one of them was gone. The king became very angry at this, and ordered the gardener to keep watch all night under the tree. The gardener set his eldest son to watch; but about twelve o’clock he fell asleep, and in the morning another of the apples was missing. Then the second son was ordered to watch; and at midnight he too fell asleep, and in the morning another apple was gone. Then the third son offered to keep watch; but the gardener at first would not let him, for fear some harm should come to him: however, at last he consented, and the young man laid himself under the tree to watch. As the clock struck twelve he heard a rustling noise in the air, and a bird came flying that was of pure gold; and as it was snapping at one of the apples with its beak, the gardener’s son jumped up and shot an arrow at it. But the arrow did the bird no harm; only it dropped a golden feather from its tail, and then flew away. The golden feather was brought to the king in the morning, and all the council was called together. Everyone agreed that it was worth more than all the wealth of the kingdom: but the king said, ‘One feather is of no use to me, I must have the whole bird.’

events.title: The Elder Sons' Disregard for Counsel and Subsequent Failures
detailed_summary: The gardener's eldest son embarked on a quest for the golden bird, expecting an easy search.
Early in his journey, he encountered a fox near a wood and prepared to shoot it.
The fox implored him not to shoot, offering valuable advice regarding his quest for the golden bird.
The fox forewarned him about a village with two opposing inns he would reach by evening, advising him to choose the poorer-looking one over the pleasant, beautiful one.
The son internally dismissed the fox's advice, doubting a mere animal's wisdom, and shot at the fox but missed as it escaped into the wood.
Upon reaching the village, he found one inn lively with singing, dancing, and feasting, while the other appeared dirty and impoverished.
Believing it foolish to choose the shabby inn over the charming one, he entered the luxurious establishment, indulged himself, and forgot about the golden bird and his homeland.
After a significant time passed with no news from the eldest son, the second son set out on the same quest.
He encountered the same fox, who provided the identical counsel about the inns.
However, upon arriving at the village, the second son saw his eldest brother at the window of the merry inn, beckoning him inside.
Unable to resist the allure, he entered, and similarly forgot his quest for the golden bird and his country.

events.text_segment:
Then the gardener’s eldest son set out and thought to find the golden bird very easily; and when he had gone but a little way, he came to a wood, and by the side of the wood he saw a fox sitting; so he took his bow and made ready to shoot at it. Then the fox said, ‘Do not shoot me, for I will give you good counsel; I know what your business is, and that you want to find the golden bird. You will reach a village in the evening; and when you get there, you will see two inns opposite to each other, one of which is very pleasant and beautiful to look at: go not in there, but rest for the night in the other, though it may appear to you to be very poor and mean.’ But the son thought to himself, ‘What can such a beast as this know about the matter?’ So he shot his arrow at the fox; but he missed it, and it set up its tail above its back and ran into the wood. Then he went his way, and in the evening came to the village where the two inns were; and in one of these were people singing, and dancing, and feasting; but the other looked very dirty, and poor. ‘I should be very silly,’ said he, ‘if I went to that shabby house, and left this charming place’; so he went into the smart house, and ate and drank at his ease, and forgot the bird, and his country too.
Time passed on; and as the eldest son did not come back, and no tidings were heard of him, the second son set out, and the same thing happened to him. He met the fox, who gave him the good advice: but when he came to the two inns, his eldest brother was standing at the window where the merrymaking was, and called to him to come in; and he could not withstand the temptation, but went in, and forgot the golden bird and his country in the same manner.

events.title: The Youngest Son's Wisdom: Heeding the Fox's Initial Advice
detailed_summary: As time continued to pass, the youngest son also expressed a desire to venture out and find the golden bird.
His father, deeply fond of him and fearing misfortune similar to his brothers, resisted for a long time.
Eventually, due to the son's persistence and unwillingness to stay home, his father consented to the journey.
Upon reaching the wood, the youngest son met the fox, who offered him the same advice given to his brothers.
Unlike his siblings, the youngest son was grateful to the fox and made no attempt to harm it.
Pleased with his attitude, the fox offered to help him travel faster if he sat on its tail.
The son accepted, and the fox ran with such speed over obstacles that their hair whistled in the wind.
When they arrived at the village, the youngest son followed the fox's guidance without hesitation, choosing the shabby inn for his overnight stay, where he rested comfortably.
The next morning, as he was about to continue his journey, the fox met him again with further instructions.
The fox directed him to a castle where soldiers would be asleep, telling him to proceed through the castle to a room where the golden bird was kept in a wooden cage.
Crucially, the fox warned him not to transfer the bird from its plain wooden cage to a nearby beautiful golden cage, or he would regret it.
The fox then extended its tail once more, and they sped off again with great velocity.

Time passed on again, and the youngest son too wished to set out into the wide world to seek for the golden bird; but his father would not listen to it for a long while, for he was very fond of his son, and was afraid that some ill luck might happen to him also, and prevent his coming back. However, at last it was agreed he should go, for he would not rest at home; and as he came to the wood, he met the fox, and heard the same good counsel. But he was thankful to the fox, and did not attempt his life as his brothers had done; so the fox said, ‘Sit upon my tail, and you will travel faster.’ So he sat down, and the fox began to run, and away they went over stock and stone so quick that their hair whistled in the wind.
When they came to the village, the son followed the fox’s counsel, and without looking about him went to the shabby inn and rested there all night at his ease. In the morning came the fox again and met him as he was beginning his journey, and said, ‘Go straight forward, till you come to a castle, before which lie a whole troop of soldiers fast asleep and snoring: take no notice of them, but go into the castle and pass on and on till you come to a room, where the golden bird sits in a wooden cage; close by it stands a beautiful golden cage; but do not try to take the bird out of the shabby cage and put it into the handsome one, otherwise you will repent it.’ Then the fox stretched out his tail again, and the young man sat himself down, and away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled in the wind.

events.title: The First Test: The Allure of the Golden Cage Leads to Capture
characters: King (of the castle with the bird)
detailed_summary: Upon reaching the castle, the son found everything as the fox had described: soldiers asleep at the gate.
He entered the castle and located the chamber where the golden bird resided in a simple wooden cage.
Nearby stood an ornate golden cage, and beside it lay the three missing golden apples.
The son thought it would be peculiar to carry such a magnificent bird in its current shabby container.
He opened the wooden cage's door, took the bird, and placed it into the golden cage.
Instantly, the bird let out a piercing scream, awakening all the sleeping soldiers.
The soldiers apprehended him and brought him before the king of that castle.
The following morning, the court convened to pass judgment on him.
After hearing the case, he was condemned to death unless he could bring the king the golden horse, renowned for its incredible speed.
If he succeeded in this task, he would be granted the golden bird as his own possession.

The son sat on the fox's tail, and they journeyed rapidly once more.

events.text_segment:
So he set out once more on his journey, sighing, and in great despair, when on a sudden his friend the fox met him, and said, ‘You see now what has happened on account of your not listening to my counsel. I will still, however, tell you how to find the golden horse, if you will do as I bid you. You must go straight on till you come to the castle where the horse stands in his stall: by his side will lie the groom fast asleep and snoring: take away the horse quietly, but be sure to put the old leathern saddle upon him, and not the golden one that is close by it.’ Then the son sat down on the fox’s tail, and away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled in the wind.
All went right, and the groom lay snoring with his hand upon the golden saddle. But when the son looked at the horse, he thought it a great pity to put the leathern saddle upon it. ‘I will give him the good one,’ said he; ‘I am sure he deserves it.’ As he took up the golden saddle the groom awoke and cried out so loud, that all the guards ran in and took him prisoner, and in the morning he was again brought before the court to be judged, and was sentenced to die. But it was agreed, that, if he could bring thither the beautiful princess, he should live, and have the bird and the horse given him for his own.

events.title: The Third Test: A Moment of Compassion Leads to a Third Capture

Despite this, the fox offered counsel once more.
He was to travel straight ahead until evening, when he would reach a castle.
At midnight, the princess would go to the bathing-house; he was to approach her, give her a kiss, and she would agree to be led away by him.
The fox sternly warned him not to permit her to say farewell to her parents.
The fox then stretched out its tail, and they sped off rapidly.
Upon arriving at the castle, events unfolded as the fox had foretold.
At twelve o'clock, the young man encountered the princess on her way to the bath and kissed her.
She consented to elope with him but pleaded tearfully for permission to bid her father goodbye.
Initially, he refused, but her persistent weeping and her falling at his feet eventually swayed him to agree.
The instant she reached her father's residence, the guards awoke, and the young man was captured yet again.

At midnight, the princess will go to the bathhouse—walk up to her and kiss her, and she will agree to leave with you. Just be sure not to allow her to say goodbye to her parents.' Then the fox extended his tail, and off they went, moving swiftly over countryside and rocky ground.

At midnight, the young man met the princess on her way to the bath, kissed her, and she promised to escape with him, but pleaded with tears to let her say farewell to her father. events.title: Hans Receives Payment and Trades Silver for a Horse
detailed_summary: The narrative opens by describing a category of individuals blessed with innate good fortune, introducing Hans as such a person.
After completing seven years of dedicated work, Hans informed his master of his intention to return home to his mother and requested his due wages.
The master, pleased with Hans's loyal service, paid him with a substantial lump of silver, comparable in size to Hans's head.
Hans secured the silver in his pocket-handkerchief, slung it over his shoulder, and set off towards his home.

While trudging along, he observed a man riding a horse with apparent ease and comfort, and Hans audibly wished for such a pleasant mode of travel, contrasting it with the discomfort of carrying his heavy silver.
The horseman overheard Hans's remarks and inquired why Hans was walking.
Hans explained his burden, highlighting the silver's weight and the pain it caused his shoulder.
The horseman proposed an exchange: his horse for Hans's silver, suggesting it would relieve Hans of his heavy load.
Hans enthusiastically accepted the offer, even expressing concern for the horseman's future task of carrying the silver, perceiving the horseman's offer as an act of kindness.
The exchange was made, and the horseman provided Hans with instructions on how to make the horse go faster by smacking his lips and shouting "Jip!".

events.text_segment:
Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster. The world may very likely not always think of them as they think of themselves, but what care they for the world? what can it know about the matter?
One of these lucky beings was neighbour Hans. Seven long years he had worked hard for his master. At last he said, ‘Master, my time is up; I must go home and see my poor mother once more: so pray pay me my wages and let me go.’ And the master said, ‘You have been a faithful and good servant, Hans, so your pay shall be handsome.’ Then he gave him a lump of silver as big as his head.
Hans took out his pocket-handkerchief, put the piece of silver into it, threw it over his shoulder, and jogged off on his road homewards. As he went lazily on, dragging one foot after another, a man came in sight, trotting gaily along on a capital horse. ‘Ah!’ said Hans aloud, ‘what a fine thing it is to ride on horseback! There he sits as easy and happy as if he was at home, in the chair by his fireside; he trips against no stones, saves shoe-leather, and gets on he hardly knows how.’ Hans did not speak so softly but the horseman heard it all, and said, ‘Well, friend, why do you go on foot then?’ ‘Ah!’ said he, ‘I have this load to carry: to be sure it is silver, but it is so heavy that I can’t hold up my head, and you must know it hurts my shoulder sadly.’ ‘What do you say of making an exchange?’ said the horseman. ‘I will give you my horse, and you shall give me the silver; which will save you a great deal of trouble in carrying such a heavy load about with you.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said Hans: ‘but as you are so kind to me, I must tell you one thing—you will have a weary task to draw that silver about with you.’ However, the horseman got off, took the silver, helped Hans up, gave him the bridle into one hand and the whip into the other, and said, ‘When you want to go very fast, smack your lips loudly together, and cry “Jip!”’

Some individuals seem destined for good fortune; whatever they attempt or undertake is successful, everything that comes their way is beneficial, all their simple possessions turn out to be valuable, and their every move is advantageous. No matter how they are challenged, they will always land safely, like a cat, and simply move forward more quickly. The world might not always see them as favorably as they see themselves, but they are unconcerned with global opinion; what insight could others possibly have into their circumstances?

One such fortunate individual was their neighbor, Hans. After working diligently for his employer for seven full years, he eventually stated, 'Master, my contracted time is finished; I must return home to see my poor mother one last time. Please pay me my wages and allow me to depart.' His master replied, 'Hans, you have been a loyal and excellent servant, so your payment will be generous.' With that, he presented Hans with a lump of silver as large as his own head.

Hans retrieved his handkerchief, placed the silver chunk inside, slung it over his shoulder, and set off toward his home. As he walked along at a relaxed pace, shuffling his feet, he saw a man approaching, riding cheerfully on an excellent horse. 'Oh!' Hans exclaimed to himself, 'how wonderful it must be to travel on horseback! He looks completely comfortable and content, as if he were sitting in his favorite chair by the fireplace at home. He avoids stumbling over rocks, saves wear and tear on his shoes, and progresses effortlessly.' Hans's words were loud enough for the rider to hear, and the man asked, 'Well, friend, why are you walking then?' 'Ah!' he replied, 'I am burdened by this load; it is silver, of course, but it is so weighty that I can scarcely lift my head, and it is truly causing pain to my shoulder.' The horseman proposed, 'How about we make a trade? I will give you my horse, and you can give me the silver. This way, you'll avoid the great difficulty of carrying such a heavy load.' Hans responded, 'With pleasure! But since you are being so kind, I must warn you about one thing—you will find it a tiresome task to haul that silver around.' Nonetheless, the horseman dismounted, took the silver, helped Hans climb onto the horse, placed the reins in one hand and the whip in the other, and instructed, 'When you wish to go very fast, make a loud smacking sound with your lips and shout "Jip!"'

events.title: A Brief Ride, a Fall, and a Trade: Horse for Cow
detailed_summary: Initially, Hans was thrilled with his new horse, riding along joyfully, whistling and singing a song about being carefree.
He decided to increase his speed and, using the command "Jip!", caused the horse to bolt into a full gallop.
Before Hans could react, he was thrown from the horse and landed on his back by the roadside.

events.title: The Unproductive Cow and Trading for a Pig
detailed_summary: After tidying himself up, Hans drove his new cow along, feeling very fortunate about his latest bargain.
He daydreamed about enjoying bread with his own butter and cheese, and drinking fresh milk whenever he was thirsty, considering these things the epitome of contentment.
Upon reaching an inn, he stopped, ate all the bread he had, and spent his very last penny on a glass of beer.
Continuing his journey towards his mother's village, he found himself on a vast, hot heath as noon approached, becoming extremely thirsty.
Confident he could remedy his thirst, Hans attempted to milk the cow, tying her to a tree and using his cap as a pail, only to discover she yielded no milk at all.
During his clumsy and unsuccessful milking efforts, the cow grew agitated and delivered a kick to Hans's head, rendering him unconscious for a significant time.
Fortunately, a butcher driving a pig in a wheelbarrow came by and helped Hans to his feet.
Hans recounted his unfortunate experience with the dry cow.
The butcher offered Hans a flask of ale and explained that the cow was old and only fit for slaughter, not for providing milk.
Hans lamented this turn of events, expressing regret over trading his horse for a useless cow and wishing he had a pig instead, which could at least be used for sausages.
The butcher, framing it as a kind and neighborly gesture, offered to exchange his pig for Hans's cow.
Hans accepted with gratitude, gave the cow to the butcher, took the pig, and continued his journey, feeling that his previous misfortunes were now fully rectified by this new acquisition.

events.text_segment:
Hans brushed his coat, wiped his face and hands, rested a while, and then drove off his cow quietly, and thought his bargain a very lucky one. ‘If I have only a piece of bread (and I certainly shall always be able to get that), I can, whenever I like, eat my butter and cheese with it; and when I am thirsty I can milk my cow and drink the milk: and what can I wish for more?’ When he came to an inn, he halted, ate up all his bread, and gave away his last penny for a glass of beer. When he had rested himself he set off again, driving his cow towards his mother’s village. But the heat grew greater as soon as noon came on, till at last, as he found himself on a wide heath that would take him more than an hour to cross, he began to be so hot and parched that his tongue clave to the roof of his mouth. ‘I can find a cure for this,’ thought he; ‘now I will milk my cow and quench my thirst’: so he tied her to the stump of a tree, and held his leathern cap to milk into; but not a drop was to be had. Who would have thought that this cow, which was to bring him milk and butter and cheese, was all that time utterly dry? Hans had not thought of looking to that.
While he was trying his luck in milking, and managing the matter very clumsily, the uneasy beast began to think him very troublesome; and at last gave him such a kick on the head as knocked him down; and there he lay a long while senseless. Luckily a butcher soon came by, driving a pig in a wheelbarrow. ‘What is the matter with you, my man?’ said the butcher, as he helped him up. Hans told him what had happened, how he was dry, and wanted to milk his cow, but found the cow was dry too. Then the butcher gave him a flask of ale, saying, ‘There, drink and refresh yourself; your cow will give you no milk: don’t you see she is an old beast, good for nothing but the slaughter-house?’ ‘Alas, alas!’ said Hans, ‘who would have thought it? What a shame to take my horse, and give me only a dry cow! If I kill her, what will she be good for? I hate cow-beef; it is not tender enough for me. If it were a pig now—like that fat gentleman you are driving along at his ease—one could do something with it; it would at any rate make sausages.’ ‘Well,’ said the butcher, ‘I don’t like to say no, when one is asked to do a kind, neighbourly thing. To please you I will change, and give you my fine fat pig for the cow.’ ‘Heaven reward you for your kindness and self-denial!’ said Hans, as he gave the butcher the cow; and taking the pig off the wheel-barrow, drove it away, holding it by the string that was tied to its leg.
So on he jogged, and all seemed now to go right with him: he had met with some misfortunes, to be sure; but he was now well repaid for all. How could it be otherwise with such a travelling companion as he had at last got?

The countryman suggested an exchange: Hans's pig for the goose, portraying this as a kind act to save Hans from the scrape, though hinting it was an unequal trade in Hans's favor.

events.text_segment:
The next man he met was a countryman carrying a fine white goose. The countryman stopped to ask what was o’clock; this led to further chat; and Hans told him all his luck, how he had so many good bargains, and how all the world went gay and smiling with him. The countryman then began to tell his tale, and said he was going to take the goose to a christening. ‘Feel,’ said he, ‘how heavy it is, and yet it is only eight weeks old. Whoever roasts and eats it will find plenty of fat upon it, it has lived so well!’ ‘You’re right,’ said Hans, as he weighed it in his hand; ‘but if you talk of fat, my pig is no trifle.’ Meantime the countryman began to look grave, and shook his head. ‘Hark ye!’ said he, ‘my worthy friend, you seem a good sort of fellow, so I can’t help doing you a kind turn. Your pig may get you into a scrape. In the village I just came from, the squire has had a pig stolen out of his sty. I was dreadfully afraid when I saw you that you had got the squire’s pig. If you have, and they catch you, it will be a bad job for you. The least they will do will be to throw you into the horse-pond. Can you swim?’
Poor Hans was sadly frightened. ‘Good man,’ cried he, ‘pray get me out of this scrape. I know nothing of where the pig was either bred or born; but he may have been the squire’s for aught I can tell: you know this country better than I do, take my pig and give me the goose.’ ‘I ought to have something into the bargain,’ said the countryman; ‘give a fat goose for a pig, indeed! ‘Tis not everyone would do so much for you as that. However, I will not be hard upon you, as you are in trouble.’ Then he took the string in his hand, and drove off the pig by a side path; while Hans went on the way homewards free from care. ‘After all,’ thought he, ‘that chap is pretty well taken in. I don’t care whose pig it is, but wherever it came from it has been a very good friend to me. I have much the best of the bargain. First there will be a capital roast; then the fat will find me in goose-grease for six months; and then there are all the beautiful white feathers. I will put them into my pillow, and then I am sure I shall sleep soundly without rocking. How happy my mother will be! Talk of a pig, indeed! Give me a fine fat goose.’

After Hans detailed his sequence of trades—silver for a horse, horse for a cow, cow for a pig, and pig for the goose—the grinder proposed a way for Hans to achieve true fortune.
He suggested Hans become a grinder himself, stating that all he needed was a grindstone, and offered to trade his own, slightly used grindstone for Hans's goose.
The prospect of being able to find money in his pocket whenever he wished captivated Hans, who believed this would fulfill all his desires.
Eagerly, Hans agreed to the exchange, giving up his goose for the grindstone.
The grinder handed over what he described as a common rough stone, claiming it was a superior tool capable of sharpening even an old nail if worked properly.

Hans departed with the stone, his heart light and his eyes sparkling with joy, convinced he was born under a lucky star and that people were generously helping him become rich through these favorable bargains.

As he came to the next village, he saw a scissor-grinder with his wheel, working and singing,
"O’er hill and o’er dale
So happy I roam,
Work light and live well,
All the world is my home;
Then who so blythe, so merry as I?"
Hans stood looking on for a while, and at last said, ‘You must be well off, master grinder! you seem so happy at your work.’ ‘Yes,’ said the other, ‘mine is a golden trade; a good grinder never puts his hand into his pocket without finding money in it—but where did you get that beautiful goose?’ ‘I did not buy it, I gave a pig for it.’ ‘And where did you get the pig?’ ‘I gave a cow for it.’ ‘And the cow?’ ‘I gave a horse for it.’ ‘And the horse?’ ‘I gave a lump of silver as big as my head for it.’ ‘And the silver?’ ‘Oh! I worked hard for that seven long years.’ ‘You have thriven well in the world hitherto,’ said the grinder, ‘now if you could find money in your pocket whenever you put your hand in it, your fortune would be made.’ ‘Very true: but how is that to be managed?’ ‘How? Why, you must turn grinder like myself,’ said the other; ‘you only want a grindstone; the rest will come of itself. Here is one that is but little the worse for wear: I would not ask more than the value of your goose for it—will you buy?’ ‘How can you ask?’ said Hans; ‘I should be the happiest man in the world, if I could have money whenever I put my hand in my pocket: what could I want more? there’s the goose.’ ‘Now,’ said the grinder, as he gave him a common rough stone that lay by his side, ‘this is a most capital stone; do but work it well enough, and you can make an old nail cut with it.’
Hans took the stone, and went his way with a light heart: his eyes sparkled for joy, and he said to himself, ‘Surely I must have been born in a lucky hour; everything I could want or wish for comes of itself. People are so kind; they seem really to think I do them a favour in letting them make me rich, and giving me good bargains.’

events.title: The Enchanted Castle and the Fairy's Curse
detailed_summary: An ancient castle in a dark forest was home to an old fairy with shapeshifting abilities.
By day, she would transform into an owl or a cat, but at night, she reverted to her form as an old woman.
Any young man who ventured within a hundred paces of her castle would be magically frozen in place until she released him, on the condition he never returned.
However, any pretty maiden who came within that same distance was turned into a bird, caged, and hung in a chamber within the castle.
The castle contained seven hundred such cages, each holding a beautiful bird.

events.text_segment: There was once an old castle, that stood in the middle of a deep gloomy wood, and in the castle lived an old fairy. Now this fairy could take any shape she pleased. All the day long she flew about in the form of an owl, or crept about the country like a cat; but at night she always became an old woman again. When any young man came within a hundred paces of her castle, he became quite fixed, and could not move a step till she came and set him free; which she would not do till he had given her his word never to come there again: but when any pretty maiden came within that space she was changed into a bird, and the fairy put her into a cage, and hung her up in a chamber in the castle. There were seven hundred of these cages hanging in the castle, and all with beautiful birds in them.

events.title: Jorinda and Jorindel's Fateful Walk and Growing Unease
detailed_summary: A maiden named Jorinda, renowned for her exceptional beauty, was betrothed to a shepherd lad named Jorindel who loved her dearly.
One day, they sought solitude by walking together in the woods.
Jorindel voiced a caution, reminding Jorinda that they needed to be careful not to stray too close to the fairy's castle.
The evening was idyllic, with the sun's fading rays illuminating the forest floor and turtle-doves cooing from the birch trees.
As Jorinda and Jorindel sat together, an inexplicable sadness overcame them, accompanied by a strong premonition that they were about to be separated forever.
They realized they had wandered a significant distance and were now lost, unsure of the way back home.

Now there was once a maiden whose name was Jorinda. Jorinda sat down to gaze upon the sun; Jorindel sat by her side; and both felt sad, they knew not why; but it seemed as if they were to be parted from one another for ever. They had wandered a long way; and when they looked to see which way they should go home, they found themselves at a loss to know what path to take.

events.title: Jorinda's Transformation and Capture by the Fairy
detailed_summary: As the sun rapidly descended, Jorindel looked around and realized with dread that they had unknowingly sat down very close to the old castle walls.
He was struck with fear, turning pale and trembling.
Jorinda was in the midst of singing a plaintive song about a ring-dove mourning its lost mate.
Her song was abruptly cut short as she was magically transformed into a nightingale, her voice ending in a bird's mournful call.
An owl with fiery eyes, revealed to be the fairy in disguise, circled them three times while emitting piercing screeches.
Jorindel found himself completely paralyzed by a spell, unable to move, weep, or speak.
The sun fully set, plunging the woods into darkness; the owl flew into a nearby bush.
A moment later, the old fairy emerged in her human form—pale, gaunt, with staring eyes and features so sharp her nose and chin nearly touched.
She muttered something under her breath, then seized the nightingale (Jorinda) and carried it away.

  Well-a-day! Well-a-day!
  He mourn’d for the fate of his darling mate,
  Well-a-day!’

Jorindel could not move; he stood fixed as a stone, and could neither weep, nor speak, nor stir hand or foot. detailed_summary: The wolf comforted Sultan and outlined a clever strategy to save him.
According to the plan, when the shepherd and his wife were in the field with their child, the wolf would emerge from the woods and pretend to abduct the child.
Sultan was instructed to lie near the child as if guarding it, then vigorously chase the wolf, who would then drop the child.
Sultan would then retrieve the child, appearing as its savior to his master and mistress.
The plan was executed perfectly; the wolf ran off with the child, the parents screamed, Sultan pursued and brought the child back.
Overjoyed and grateful, the shepherd declared that Sultan had saved their child and would be cared for, well-fed, and even given the shepherd's old cushion to sleep on for the rest of his life.
From that point on, Sultan enjoyed a life of comfort and abundance.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So from this time forward Sultan had all that he could wish for.

events.text_segment: ‘Make yourself easy,’ said the wolf, ‘I will give you some good advice. Your master, you know, goes out every morning very early with his wife into the field; and they take their little child with them, and lay it down behind the hedge in the shade while they are at work. Now do you lie down close by the child, and pretend to be watching it, and I will come out of the wood and run away with it; you must run after me as fast as you can, and I will let it drop; then you may carry it back, and they will think you have saved their child, and will be so thankful to you that they will take care of you as long as you live.’ The dog liked this plan very well; and accordingly so it was managed. The wolf ran with the child a little way; the shepherd and his wife screamed out; but Sultan soon overtook him, and carried the poor little thing back to his master and mistress. Then the shepherd patted him on the head, and said, ‘Old Sultan has saved our child from the wolf, and therefore he shall live and be well taken care of, and have plenty to eat. Wife, go home, and give him a good dinner, and let him have my old cushion to sleep on as long as he lives.’ So from this time forward Sultan had all that he could wish for.

events.title: The Wolf's Demand and Sultan's Unwavering Loyalty
detailed_summary: Shortly after, the wolf visited Sultan to congratulate him on their success.
The wolf then suggested that as a form of repayment, Sultan should look the other way if the wolf decided to take one of the shepherd's sheep.
Sultan firmly refused, asserting his unwavering loyalty to his master.
The wolf, believing Sultan was not serious, later attempted to steal a sheep during the night.
However, Sultan had already warned his master about the wolf's intentions.
The shepherd lay in wait and, as the wolf was selecting a sheep, ambushed him with a heavy cudgel, giving him a severe beating.

The following morning, the wolf dispatched the boar to challenge Sultan to a duel in the woods to settle their dispute.
Sultan, finding no other companion to act as his second in the fight, decided to take the shepherd's old, three-legged cat with him.
The cat, struggling somewhat due to her limp, walked with her tail held stiffly upright in the air.

events.title: Foes Misinterpret Cat's Appearance, Leading to Their Cowardly Retreat
detailed_summary: The wolf and the wild boar were the first to arrive at the agreed-upon location for the duel.
When they saw Sultan and the cat approaching, they misinterpreted the cat's erect tail, believing it to be a sword that Sultan intended to use.
Furthermore, each time the limping cat paused, they thought she was bending down to pick up a stone to hurl at them.
Feeling uneasy about this perceived method of combat, they decided against fighting.
Consequently, the boar concealed himself behind a bush, and the wolf hastily climbed up into a tree.
Sultan and the cat soon arrived at the spot, looking around and wondering why their adversaries were not present.

detailed_summary: The boar hadn't managed to hide completely, as his ears were visible protruding from the bush.
When the boar twitched one of his ears, the cat, mistaking the movement for that of a mouse, pounced on it, biting and scratching.
Startled and in pain, the boar leaped up, grunted, and fled, shouting out that the one responsible for the trouble was hiding in the tree, thereby revealing the wolf's location.
Sultan and the cat then looked up and saw the wolf perched among the tree branches.
They derided him as a cowardly scoundrel and refused to allow him to come down until he expressed genuine remorse and promised to reconcile and be friends with old Sultan again.

chapters.chapter_title: THE STRAW, THE COAL, AND THE BEAN

events.title: An Unlikely Encounter and Shared Escapes
detailed_summary: An impoverished elderly woman gathered beans for cooking.
She started a fire on her hearth using straw for kindling.
While transferring beans to a pan, one bean fell unnoticed to the ground, landing near a piece of straw.
A burning coal then leaped from the fire, joining the bean and straw.
The straw initiated a conversation, inquiring about the origins of the bean and coal.
The coal recounted its fortunate escape from the fire, which would have otherwise reduced it to ashes.
The bean shared its own narrow escape, explaining that it would have been boiled into broth with its companions if the old woman had put it in the pan.
The straw lamented the fate of its fellow straws, all destroyed by fire and smoke by the old woman, and expressed relief at its own accidental escape.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I luckily slipped through her fingers.’

events.text_segment: In a village dwelt a poor old woman, who had gathered together a dish of beans and wanted to cook them. So she made a fire on her hearth, and that it might burn the quicker, she lighted it with a handful of straw. When she was emptying the beans into the pan, one dropped without her observing it, and lay on the ground beside a straw, and soon afterwards a burning coal from the fire leapt down to the two. Then the straw began and said: ‘Dear friends, from whence do you come here?’ The coal replied: ‘I fortunately sprang out of the fire, and if I had not escaped by sheer force, my death would have been certain,—I should have been burnt to ashes.’ The bean said: ‘I too have escaped with a whole skin, but if the old woman had got me into the pan, I should have been made into broth without any mercy, like my comrades.’ ‘And would a better fate have fallen to my lot?’ said the straw. ‘The old woman has destroyed all my brethren in fire and smoke; she seized sixty of them at once, and took their lives. I luckily slipped through her fingers.’

events.title: A Pact for a Shared Journey
detailed_summary: The coal posed the question of their next course of action.
The bean proposed that, having all narrowly avoided death, they should remain together as companions.
Furthermore, the bean suggested they depart their current location to seek refuge in a foreign land, thereby avoiding potential new dangers.
This plan was met with approval from both the straw and the coal.
The three companions then embarked on their journey together.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘But what are we to do now?’ said the coal.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The proposition pleased the two others, and they set out on their way together.

events.text_segment:
‘But what are we to do now?’ said the coal.
‘I think,’ answered the bean, ‘that as we have so fortunately escaped death, we should keep together like good companions, and lest a new mischance should overtake us here, we should go away together, and repair to a foreign country.’
The proposition pleased the two others, and they set out on their way together.

The bean responded, proposing that since they had been fortunate enough to survive, they should remain united as good companions. To prevent another misfortune from befalling them in that location, they should depart together and travel to a different land. The other two found this suggestion agreeable, and they all started their journey together.

events.title: The Perilous Brook Crossing and Tragic Demise
detailed_summary: The companions soon reached a small brook, but found no bridge or plank to cross it.
They were uncertain about how to proceed.
The straw devised a plan, offering to lay itself across the water to serve as a makeshift bridge.
The straw then stretched itself from one bank of the brook to the other.
The coal, described as having an impetuous nature, boldly stepped onto the straw bridge.
However, upon reaching the middle of the brook and hearing the sound of the water flowing beneath, the coal became frightened and hesitated, unable to move further.
The straw, likely ignited by the coal or strained by its weight, began to burn, broke into two pieces, and fell into the stream.
The coal followed, slipping into the water, where it sizzled and was extinguished.

events.title: The Bean's Explosive Laughter and Fortuitous Mending
detailed_summary: The bean, having cautiously remained on the shore, witnessed the unfortunate end of its companions.
The bean found the incident overwhelmingly funny and began to laugh uncontrollably.
Its laughter was so intense and hearty that the bean eventually burst open.
The bean's fate would have been sealed then, had it not been for the timely arrival of a tailor, who was journeying in search of employment and had stopped to rest by the brook.
Possessing a kind heart, the tailor took out his needle and thread and sewed the burst bean back together.
The bean expressed its sincere gratitude to the tailor for his help.
The narrative concludes by explaining that because the tailor used black thread for the repair, all beans since that time have a characteristic black seam.

events.title: The Barren Royal Couple and the Fish's Prophecy of a Daughter
detailed_summary: A royal couple, despite their riches, were deeply saddened by their inability to conceive a child after many years of marriage.
One day, the queen, while near a river in her garden, showed compassion to a small fish that had beached itself and was close to dying by returning it to the water.

Before departing, the rescued fish informed the queen that it was aware of her desire for a child and, as a token of gratitude for her kindness, prophesied that she would soon give birth to a daughter.
This prophecy was fulfilled when the queen bore an exceptionally beautiful baby girl.
The king was filled with immense joy at the sight of his daughter and announced his intention to host a magnificent feast to introduce the princess to the entire realm.

events.text_segment: A king and queen once upon a time reigned in a country a great way off, where there were in those days fairies. Now this king and queen had plenty of money, and plenty of fine clothes to wear, and plenty of good things to eat and drink, and a coach to ride out in every day: but though they had been married many years they had no children, and this grieved them very much indeed. But one day as the queen was walking by the side of the river, at the bottom of the garden, she saw a poor little fish, that had thrown itself out of the water, and lay gasping and nearly dead on the bank. Then the queen took pity on the little fish, and threw it back again into the river; and before it swam away it lifted its head out of the water and said, ‘I know what your wish is, and it shall be fulfilled, in return for your kindness to me—you will soon have a daughter.’ What the little fish had foretold soon came to pass; and the queen had a little girl, so very beautiful that the king could not cease looking on it for joy, and said he would hold a great feast and make merry, and show the child to all the land.

Before swimming away, the fish poked its head out and promised the queen her wish would come true as a reward for her kindness—that she would soon have a daughter. Soon thereafter, just as the fish had promised, the queen gave birth to a beautiful girl. The king was overjoyed and decided to host a grand celebration to present their daughter to the kingdom.

events.title: The Christening Feast and the Fairies' Gifts
detailed_summary: The king extended invitations for the celebratory feast to his relatives, aristocracy, companions, and local inhabitants.
The queen particularly insisted on inviting the fairies, hoping they would bestow their blessings and goodwill upon their newborn daughter.
Although there were thirteen fairies residing in the kingdom, the king and queen possessed only twelve golden plates suitable for serving such esteemed guests.
As a result, one of the fairies was consequently omitted from the guest list and did not receive an invitation.
Twelve fairies attended the event, each distinguished by a tall red hat, red high-heeled footwear, and a long white magical staff.
Following the conclusion of the banquet, these fairies convened in a circle around the infant princess to grant her their most precious gifts.
These endowments included qualities like virtue, attractiveness, and wealth, collectively ensuring the princess would possess all desirable attributes in the world.

events.title: The Thirteenth Fairy's Curse and the Twelfth Fairy's Intervention
detailed_summary: Just as the eleventh fairy concluded her blessing, a significant disturbance was reported from the courtyard, signaling the arrival of the thirteenth fairy, who had not been invited.
This fairy made her entrance into the dining hall, characterized by a black cap, black footwear, and carrying a broomstick.
Incensed by her exclusion from the feast, she severely reprimanded the king and queen and immediately plotted her retribution.
She then proclaimed a curse: the king's daughter, upon reaching her fifteenth year, would suffer an injury from a spindle and consequently die.
At this point, the twelfth of the benevolent fairies, who had yet to bestow her gift, came forward.
She explained that while the malevolent curse was destined to be fulfilled, she possessed the ability to mitigate its harshness.
Her gift, therefore, was to alter the curse so that when the princess was wounded by the spindle, she would not truly perish but instead fall into a profound slumber lasting one hundred years.

events.title: The King's Precaution and the Inevitable Fulfillment of Prophecy
detailed_summary: The king, in a desperate attempt to completely shield his beloved daughter from the prophesied misfortune, issued a decree that all spindles within the kingdom were to be acquired and subsequently destroyed by fire.

Meanwhile, the positive attributes gifted by the initial eleven fairies fully manifested in the princess; she developed into a person of such beauty, grace, goodness, and wisdom that she was adored by everyone acquainted with her.
On the very day she attained the age of fifteen, her parents, the king and queen, were absent from the palace, leaving her by herself.
The princess took the opportunity to wander through the palace, exploring its many rooms and chambers.
Her exploration led her eventually to an ancient tower, accessed by a constricted staircase that terminated at a small door.
A golden key was present in this door; upon turning it, the door swung open, revealing an elderly woman inside, diligently occupied with spinning.
The princess, addressing the woman politely, inquired about her activity, to which the old lady replied she was spinning, nodding and humming as her wheel spun.
Captivated by the motion of the spinning apparatus, the princess expressed her admiration and took the spindle, intending to try spinning herself.
However, almost immediately upon her touching it, the fairy's curse came to pass; the spindle pricked her, and she collapsed to the ground, appearing lifeless.

events.title: The Enchanted Slumber Descends Upon the Palace
detailed_summary: The princess had not died, but rather had succumbed to a very deep sleep.
The king and queen, who had just arrived back at the palace, along with their entire retinue, also fell into a slumber.
This magical sleep permeated the entire palace grounds: horses dozed in their stalls, dogs slept in the courtyard, pigeons rested on the rooftop, and even flies remained motionless on the walls.

The enchantment extended to inanimate objects as well: the fire in the hearth ceased its burning and appeared to sleep; the mechanism turning the roasting spit stopped, and the spit itself, holding a goose for the king's meal, became still.
The cook, in the midst of pulling a kitchen-boy's hair to reprimand him, was frozen in the act, and both she and the boy fell asleep.
The butler, who was surreptitiously tasting the ale, also fell asleep with the drinking vessel poised at his lips.
In this manner, every person and object within the palace came to a halt and entered a state of profound sleep.

events.title: The Thorn Hedge Encircles the Sleeping Palace
detailed_summary: A substantial barrier of thorns quickly materialized around the palace, growing taller and denser with each passing year.
Ultimately, the historic palace became entirely enveloped and obscured by this thorny growth, so much so that even its roof and chimneys were no longer visible.
Nevertheless, tales of the exquisitely beautiful sleeping princess, who came to be known as Briar Rose, circulated throughout the surrounding lands.
Consequently, over a period of time, several sons of kings were drawn by these accounts and made attempts to force their way through the dense thicket to reach the enchanted palace.
None of these aspirants, however, were ever successful in their endeavors; the thorns and bushes seemed to actively seize them, as if with hands.
These unfortunate princes found themselves trapped fast within the thorny barrier and ultimately met with a miserable demise.

events.title: A Prince Hears the Legend of Briar Rose and Resolves to Find Her
detailed_summary: After a great many years had passed, a king's son journeyed into that particular region.

An elderly man there recounted to him the legend of the impenetrable thorn thicket, detailing how a magnificent palace lay concealed behind it, and within, a marvelous princess named Briar Rose remained in an enchanted sleep along with her entire court.

The old man further conveyed that he had learned from his own grandfather about numerous princes who had previously come and attempted to breach the thicket, but all had become ensnared and perished in their efforts.
Despite these grim accounts, the young prince declared that such stories would not deter him; he was resolved to proceed and see the famed Briar Rose for himself.
The old man made efforts to dissuade the prince from his perilous undertaking, but the prince's determination to go was unshakeable.

events.title: The Awakening Kiss and the Revival of the Palace
detailed_summary: The prince ventured further into the palace, where the silence was so profound he could hear his own respirations.
At last, he reached the old tower and unlatched the door of the small chamber where Briar Rose was located.
There she lay, deeply asleep on a couch near the window, her beauty so captivating he could not avert his gaze.
Overcome by her appearance, he bent down and bestowed a kiss upon her.
The very moment his lips touched hers, Briar Rose's eyes fluttered open, she awoke, and offered him a smile.
Together, they exited the room.
Concurrently, the king and queen also awoke, as did the entire court, all of them looking at one another with immense surprise.
The horses began to move and shake their bodies, the dogs leaped up and barked, and the pigeons lifted their heads from under their wings, surveyed their surroundings, and flew out into the fields.
The flies on the walls resumed their buzzing.
The kitchen fire flared back to life; the roasting jack and the spit began to turn once more, the goose for the king's dinner rotating upon it.
The butler completed his interrupted draught of ale, the maid recommenced plucking the fowl, and the cook finally administered the intended disciplinary rap on the ear to the kitchen boy.

events.title: A Feast for the Famished: Sparrow's Ingenuity at the Butcher's and Baker's

The sparrow landed on the butcher's shelf and, after carefully checking for observers, dislodged a steak by pecking and scratching at it until it fell.
The dog seized the fallen steak, retreated to a corner, and consumed it entirely.
The sparrow offered to get more, led the dog to another shop, and similarly obtained a second steak for him.
After the dog finished the second piece of meat, the sparrow asked if he had eaten enough.
The dog confirmed he had plenty of meat but now desired some bread.
The sparrow agreed and guided him to a baker’s establishment.
There, the sparrow skillfully pecked at two rolls in the window until they dropped down for the dog.
As the dog still wished for more, the sparrow took him to another bakery and obtained more bread in the same manner.
Once the dog had eaten this additional bread, the sparrow inquired if his hunger was now satisfied.
The dog affirmed that it was and proposed they take a short walk outside the town.

events.title: Tragedy on the High Road: The Dog's Death and the Sparrow's Vow
detailed_summary: The two companions set off along the main road, but the warm weather soon made the dog weary, and he expressed a wish to nap.
The sparrow consented, stating it would rest on a nearby bush while the dog slept.
The dog then stretched out on the road and quickly fell into a deep sleep.
While the dog slept, a carter approached with a cart pulled by three horses and carrying two wine casks.
The sparrow observed that the carter was not altering his course and was on a direct path to drive over the sleeping dog.
The sparrow called out, warning the carter to halt or face severe repercussions.
The carter, muttering dismissively about the sparrow's perceived inability to harm him, cracked his whip and proceeded.
He drove his cart directly over the poor dog, the wheels crushing the animal to death.
The sparrow then cried out, accusing the carter, whom it called a cruel villain, of killing its friend.
The sparrow declared that this act of cruelty would cost the carter all his possessions.
The carter, defiant, challenged the sparrow to inflict its worst and continued on his journey.

detailed_summary: The sparrow concealed itself beneath the cart's covering and pecked at the bung of one of the wine casks until it became loose.
Consequently, all the wine drained out from the cask without the carter immediately noticing.
Eventually, the carter looked back and saw his cart dripping and one cask entirely empty, leading him to exclaim his misfortune.
The sparrow then appeared, alighting on one of the horse's heads, and retorted that the carter was not yet wretched enough, proceeding to peck the horse until it reared and kicked.
Witnessing this, the carter retrieved his hatchet and aimed a blow at the sparrow, intending to kill it.
The sparrow, however, flew away, and the carter's strike fatally hit the horse on its head.
The carter lamented his ill luck once more, to which the sparrow responded that he was still not sufficiently wretched.
As the carter moved on with his remaining two horses, the sparrow again slipped under the cart's canvas.
It pecked out the bung of the second wine cask, causing all its contents to spill out.
When the carter discovered this new loss, he again cried out about his miserable state.
The sparrow countered that he was not wretched enough yet, then landed on the second horse's head and started pecking it.
The carter ran towards the sparrow and swung his hatchet again; the bird dodged, and the blow fell upon the second horse, killing it instantly.
The carter bemoaned his unlucky fate, and the sparrow repeated its taunting refrain.
The sparrow then perched upon the third horse and commenced pecking it as well.
The carter, now mad with fury and acting recklessly, struck at the sparrow again but ended up killing his third horse, just as he had the other two.
The carter cried out in his misery, and the sparrow, flying off, declared that he was not yet wretched enough and that it would now bring plague and punishment to his own house.

events.title: The Sparrow's Final Taunt and the Carter's Fatal Rage
detailed_summary: The carter, having witnessed the loss of all his possessions, descended to his kitchen, still showing no remorse for his actions, and sat angrily in the chimney corner.
The sparrow positioned itself outside the window and cried out that the carter's cruelty would cost him his life.

The hatchet missed the bird but shattered the windowpane.
The sparrow then hopped inside, perched upon the window-seat, and repeated its dire warning about the cost of the carter's life.
Driven mad and blind with fury, the carter struck the window-seat with such force that he split it in two.

As the sparrow darted from place to place within the room, the carter and his wife, in their furious attempts to strike it, ended up breaking all their furniture, glassware, and even damaging the walls, without managing to touch the bird.
Ultimately, however, they succeeded in capturing the sparrow.
The wife inquired if she should kill it immediately.
The carter, desiring a more agonizing end for the bird, declared that merely killing it was too lenient and that he would eat it instead.
The sparrow began to flutter and stretch its neck, crying out one final time that the carter's cruelty would yet cost him his life.
Unable to delay any longer, the carter handed his wife the hatchet and commanded her to strike the bird and kill it while he held it in his hand.
The wife swung the hatchet, but her aim was errant; she missed the sparrow and instead struck her husband on the head.
The carter fell down dead, and the sparrow flew serenely back to its nest.

events.title: The King's Perplexing Problem and a Deadly Challenge
detailed_summary: A king was troubled because his twelve daughters, despite being locked in their room each night, awoke every morning with their shoes completely worn out, as if they had danced extensively.
The origin of their nightly excursions and the cause of the worn shoes remained an unsolved puzzle.
To uncover this secret, the king issued a proclamation across his realm.
He promised that any man who could reveal where the princesses danced would win the hand of his chosen daughter in marriage and be designated as the successor to the throne.
However, the proclamation carried a dire warning: any contender who failed to solve the mystery within three days and nights would face execution.

events.text_segment:
There was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters. They slept in twelve beds all in one room; and when they went to bed, the doors were shut and locked up; but every morning their shoes were found to be quite worn through as if they had been danced in all night; and yet nobody could find out how it happened, or where they had been.
Then the king made it known to all the land, that if any person could discover the secret, and find out where it was that the princesses danced in the night, he should have the one he liked best for his wife, and should be king after his death; but whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.

However, each morning their shoes were found to be totally worn through, as if they had spent the entire night dancing, and yet no one could figure out how this occurred or where they went. The king then announced across the kingdom that anyone who could uncover this puzzle and discover where the princesses danced at night would be granted his choice of one of the princesses to marry and would inherit the throne after the king's passing. events.title: Failed Suitors and a Soldier's Chance Encounter with Magical Aid
detailed_summary: A prince was the first to accept the king's challenge, receiving good hospitality and being placed in a room adjacent to the princesses' chamber to observe them, with his door left open.
Despite these arrangements, the prince succumbed to sleep and, upon waking, found the princesses' shoes worn out, indicating they had danced.
This pattern repeated for two more nights, leading to the prince's execution by the king's order.
Several other hopefuls followed, but all met the same unfortunate end, losing their lives after failing to uncover the secret.
Subsequently, an old soldier, unable to fight due to battle wounds, journeyed through the king's land.
While traveling in a forest, he met an elderly woman who inquired about his destination.
The soldier confessed his uncertainty but expressed an interest in discovering the princesses' dancing secret, hoping it might lead him to become king.
The old woman assured him the task was not overly difficult, offering crucial advice: he must avoid drinking any wine offered by a princess in the evening and then feign deep sleep.
She also provided him with a special cloak, explaining that wearing it would render him invisible, allowing him to follow the princesses undetected.

events.text_segment:
A king’s son soon came. He was well entertained, and in the evening was taken to the chamber next to the one where the princesses lay in their twelve beds. There he was to sit and watch where they went to dance; and, in order that nothing might pass without his hearing it, the door of his chamber was left open. But the king’s son soon fell asleep; and when he awoke in the morning he found that the princesses had all been dancing, for the soles of their shoes were full of holes. The same thing happened the second and third night: so the king ordered his head to be cut off. After him came several others; but they had all the same luck, and all lost their lives in the same manner.
Now it chanced that an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, passed through the country where this king reigned: and as he was travelling through a wood, he met an old woman, who asked him where he was going. ‘I hardly know where I am going, or what I had better do,’ said the soldier; ‘but I think I should like very well to find out where it is that the princesses dance, and then in time I might be a king.’ ‘Well,’ said the old dame, ‘that is no very hard task: only take care not to drink any of the wine which one of the princesses will bring to you in the evening; and as soon as she leaves you pretend to be fast asleep.’
Then she gave him a cloak, and said, ‘As soon as you put that on you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go.’

events.title: The Soldier's Strategic Deception and the Princesses' Preparations
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the old woman's counsel, the soldier resolved to test his fortune and presented himself to the king, declaring his readiness to undertake the challenge.
He received the same courteous treatment as previous suitors, and the king provided him with fine royal attire.
As evening arrived, he was escorted to the antechamber.
Just before he intended to lie down, the eldest princess approached him with a cup of wine.
The soldier, remembering the old woman's warning, discreetly disposed of the wine without consuming any.
He then settled on his bed and soon began to snore loudly, convincingly simulating deep sleep.
The twelve princesses, hearing his snores, were amused, and the eldest remarked that he, like others before him, could have chosen a wiser path than risking his life.
They then got up, opened their storage, retrieved their elegant clothing, adorned themselves before mirrors, and moved about excitedly, eager for their nightly activity.
However, the youngest princess voiced a sense of unease amidst her sisters' happiness, fearing some misfortune.

The eldest dismissed her concerns, calling her a simpleton and reminding her of the many princes who had failed to discover their secret, adding that the soldier would have slept soundly even without the drugged wine she presumed he drank.

events.title: Unveiling the Hidden Passage and the Silver Grove
detailed_summary: Once fully prepared, the princesses observed the soldier, who continued to snore without moving, convincing them of their safety.
The eldest princess then went to her bed, clapped her hands, causing the bed to lower into the floor and reveal a trapdoor.
The soldier witnessed them descend through the opening one by one, with the eldest leading.
Realizing he needed to act quickly, he got up, donned the invisibility cloak given by the old woman, and followed.
While on the stairs, he inadvertently stepped on the gown of the youngest princess.
She exclaimed to her sisters that something was amiss, feeling someone tug her gown.
The eldest princess dismissed her alarm, casually suggesting it was merely a nail in the wall.
They all continued downwards and emerged at the bottom into a beautiful grove where all the tree leaves were made of silver, shimmering splendidly.
The soldier, wanting a memento, broke off a small silver branch, which caused a loud sound to emanate from the tree.
The youngest princess again expressed her conviction that something was wrong, questioning if her sisters heard the noise, which she noted had never occurred before.
The eldest, however, reassured them by claiming it was only their awaiting princes shouting in joyful anticipation of their arrival.

events.title: Traversing More Magical Groves and Reaching the Lakeside Rendezvous
detailed_summary: The group proceeded to a second grove where the leaves were entirely of gold.
Following that, they entered a third grove, its leaves made of sparkling diamonds.
From each of these groves, the soldier broke off a branch as a token.
Each time he did so, a loud noise occurred, causing the youngest sister to tremble with fear.
The eldest sister consistently attributed these sounds to the princes exclaiming with joy.
Their journey continued until they arrived at a large lake.
By the lake's edge, twelve small boats were waiting, each occupied by a handsome prince, apparently expecting the princesses.
One princess boarded each boat, and the invisible soldier chose to enter the boat carrying the youngest princess.
While they were being rowed across the lake, the prince in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier commented on the unusual difficulty in rowing.
He noted that despite his efforts, their progress was slower than normal and he felt quite tired, remarking that the boat seemed exceptionally heavy that day.
The youngest princess attributed his struggle to the warmth of the weather, saying she also felt very warm.

events.title: The Secret Ball, Unexplained Incidents, and the Journey Back
detailed_summary: Across the lake, they saw a splendid, brightly lit castle from which joyous music of horns and trumpets emanated.
Everyone disembarked and entered the castle, where each prince began dancing with his designated princess.
The soldier, still invisible, joined in the dancing as well.
Whenever a princess had a cup of wine placed beside her, the soldier would drink it entirely, so that the cup was empty when she lifted it to her lips.
This phenomenon particularly terrified the youngest sister, but the eldest continually quieted her.
The dancing continued until three o'clock in the morning, by which time all their shoes were completely worn through, forcing them to stop.
The princes then rowed them back across the lake; for this return trip, the soldier positioned himself in the boat with the eldest princess.
Upon reaching the opposite shore, the princesses and princes bid each other farewell, with the princesses promising to return for another night of dancing.

‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
Then the fish came swimming to him, and said, ‘Well, what is her will? Everything went right for a week or two, and then Dame Ilsabill said, ‘Husband, there is not near room enough for us in this cottage; the courtyard and the garden are a great deal too small; I should like to have a large stone castle to live in: go to the fish again and tell him to give us a castle.’ ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘I don’t like to go to him again, for perhaps he will be angry; we ought to be easy with this pretty cottage to live in.’ ‘Nonsense!’ said the wife; ‘he will do it very willingly, I know; go along and try!’
The fisherman went, but his heart was very heavy: and when he came to the sea, it looked blue and gloomy, though it was very calm; and he went close to the edge of the waves, and said:
 ‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘Well, what does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the man, dolefully, ‘my wife wants to live in a stone castle.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is standing at the gate of it already.’ So away went the fisherman, and found his wife standing before the gate of a great castle. ‘See,’ said she, ‘is not this grand?’ With that they went into the castle together, and found a great many servants there, and the rooms all richly furnished, and full of golden chairs and tables; and behind the castle was a garden, and around it was a park half a mile long, full of sheep, and goats, and hares, and deer; and in the courtyard were stables and cow-houses. ‘Well,’ said the man, ‘now we will live cheerful and happy in this beautiful castle for the rest of our lives.’ ‘Perhaps we may,’ said the wife; ‘but let us sleep upon it, before we make up our minds to that.’ So they went to bed.

Staring at her in awe, the man exclaimed, 'Oh, what a remarkable thing it is to be emperor!' Ilsabill responded, 'Husband, why should we stop at being emperor? My next step is to become pope.' The fisherman protested, 'Oh wife, wife! How can you be pope? There is only one pope in all of Christendom at any given time.' 'Husband,' she insisted, 'I will be pope this very day.' Her husband countered, 'But the fish cannot possibly make you pope.' 'Nonsense!' she retorted. 'If he can create an emperor, he can certainly create a pope. Go and ask him.' So the fisherman set off. However, when he reached the coast, a furious wind was blowing, and the sea was being violently churned into boiling waves. Ships were struggling, rolling alarmingly on the crests of the swells. Above, there was a small patch of blue sky in the center, but towards the south, the sky was red, as if a terrible storm was about to erupt. The sight terrified the fisherman; he trembled so much that his knees knocked together. Despite his fear, he approached the shore and called out: 'O man of the sea! Listen to me! My wife, Ilsabill, Insists on having her will, And has sent me to ask a favor of thee!' 'What does she desire now?' inquired the fish. 'Alas,' said the fisherman, 'my wife wishes to be pope.' 'Go home,' the fish commanded, 'she is already pope.'

events.text_segment:
Then the fisherman went home, and found Ilsabill sitting on a throne that was two miles high. And she had three great crowns on her head, and around her stood all the pomp and power of the Church. And on each side of her were two rows of burning lights, of all sizes, the greatest as large as the highest and biggest tower in the world, and the least no larger than a small rushlight. ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, as he looked at all this greatness, ‘are you pope?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am pope.’ ‘Well, wife,’ replied he, ‘it is a grand thing to be pope; and now you must be easy, for you can be nothing greater.’ ‘I will think about that,’ said the wife. Then they went to bed: but Dame Ilsabill could not sleep all night for thinking what she should be next. At last, as she was dropping asleep, morning broke, and the sun rose. ‘Ha!’ thought she, as she woke up and looked at it through the window, ‘after all I cannot prevent the sun rising.’ At this thought she was very angry, and wakened her husband, and said, ‘Husband, go to the fish and tell him I must be lord of the sun and moon.’ The fisherman was half asleep, but the thought frightened him so much that he started and fell out of bed. ‘Alas, wife!’ said he, ‘cannot you be easy with being pope?’ ‘No,’ said she, ‘I am very uneasy as long as the sun and moon rise without my leave. Go to the fish at once!’
Then the man went shivering with fear; and as he was going down to the shore a dreadful storm arose, so that the trees and the very rocks shook. And all the heavens became black with stormy clouds, and the lightnings played, and the thunders rolled; and you might have seen in the sea great black waves, swelling up like mountains with crowns of white foam upon their heads. And the fisherman crept towards the sea, and cried out, as well as he could:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘What does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said he, ‘she wants to be lord of the sun and moon.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish, ‘to your pigsty again.’
And there they live to this very day.

events.title: The Bear's Disrespectful Visit and Insult to the Wrens
detailed_summary: While walking in the forest, the bear becomes captivated by a bird's beautiful singing.
The wolf identifies the singer as the King of birds, the willow-wren, and states that they must show reverence.
The bear expresses a keen interest in seeing the willow-wren's royal palace, prompting the wolf to advise him to wait until the Queen wren makes an appearance.
Soon after, the Queen arrives with food, accompanied by the King, and they begin feeding their young.
The bear is eager to approach, but the wolf restrains him, advising they wait until the royal couple departs.
They observe the location of the nest and then leave.
Unable to contain his curiosity, the bear returns to the nest alone a short time later, when the King and Queen have flown out.
He peeps into the nest and sees five or six young wrens.
The bear mockingly questions if this is the royal palace, calling it a 'wretched palace' and deriding the young birds as 'disreputable children' instead of royal offspring.
The young wrens react with extreme anger to the insult, vehemently denying the accusations, asserting the honesty of their parents, and warning the bear that he will be made to pay for his words.

The bear would have liked to go at once, but the wolf held him back by the sleeve, and said: ‘No, you must wait until the lord and lady Queen have gone away again.’ So they took stock of the hole where the nest lay, and trotted away. The bear, however, could not rest until he had seen the royal palace, and when a short time had passed, went to it again. The King and Queen had just flown out, so he peeped in and saw five or six young ones lying there. ‘Is that the royal palace?’ cried the bear; ‘it is a wretched palace, and you are not King’s children, you are disreputable children!’ When the young wrens heard that, they were frightfully angry, and screamed: ‘No, that we are not! events.title: The Wrens' Outrage and the Declaration of War
detailed_summary: The bear and the wolf become apprehensive and retreat to their respective dens.
The young willow-wrens continue their distressed cries and, when their parents return with food, they adamantly refuse to eat.
They declare they will not touch even a fly's leg, even if starving, until their parents settle the matter of their respectability, informing them of the bear's insulting visit.
The old King wren reassures his children, promising that the bear will be punished for his actions.
He and the Queen immediately fly to the bear's cave and call in to him.
The King wren, addressing the bear as 'Old Growler,' demands to know why he insulted his children and declares that he will suffer for it through a 'bloody war.'
With war thus declared upon the Bear, all four-footed animals, including oxen, asses, cows, deer, and every other terrestrial creature, are summoned to participate.
Simultaneously, the willow-wren summons all creatures that fly, not only birds of all sizes but also midges, hornets, bees, and flies, to join his forces.

events.title: Espionage Reveals the Enemy's Battle Strategy
detailed_summary: When the time for war to commence drew near, the willow-wren dispatched spies to ascertain the identity of the enemy's commander-in-chief.
The gnat, described as the most cunning spy, flew into the forest where the enemy forces were assembled.
The gnat concealed itself beneath a leaf on the tree where the password and strategic commands were to be issued.
The bear was present and called the fox before him, appointing the fox as general due to his reputation as the most cunning of all animals.
The fox accepted the position of general and then questioned what signal they should agree upon for their maneuvers.
As no one had a suggestion, the fox proposed using his own long, bushy tail, which resembled a plume of red feathers, as the signal.
He explained that if he lifted his tail high, it meant all was going well, and the troops should charge; however, if he let it hang down, they should retreat as quickly as possible.
Having overheard this critical information, the gnat flew back and meticulously reported every detail to the willow-wren.

events.title: The Decisive Battle: The Hornet's Sting and the Birds' Victory
detailed_summary: At daybreak, as the battle was set to begin, the assembled four-footed animals charged forward, creating a noise so immense that the earth trembled.
The willow-wren, accompanied by his aerial army, also advanced, their movement generating such a humming, whirring, and swarming that it caused unease and fear in all observers.
Both armies moved to engage each other.
The willow-wren issued an order to the hornet, instructing it to position itself beneath the fox's tail and sting with all its might.
When the fox experienced the first sting, he jolted and lifted one leg in pain but managed to endure it, keeping his tail held high.
Upon receiving a second sting, the fox was compelled to lower his tail for a moment.
After the third sting, the fox could no longer bear the pain; he screamed and tucked his tail between his legs.
Witnessing this, the other animals misinterpreted the fox's lowered tail as the signal for retreat, concluded that all was lost, and began to flee, each seeking refuge in its hole.
As a result, the birds emerged victorious from the battle.
